diagnostics.notes: Mitigation can include adding a whole-house dehumidifier, implementing controls to lower blower speed for longer runtimes, or ultimately replacing with a correctly sized unit. In some cases, an oversized multi-stage system can be tweaked to operate mostly on lower stage.
evidence_snippets: High humidity is caused by short compressor run-time from oversized systems. The APR Control reduces capacity, extending runtime for effective dehumidification.:contentReference[oaicite:99]{index=99}

diagnostics.specific_diagnostic_name: Refrigerant lines kinked or wrong size
diagnostics.description: The refrigerant line-set has physical kinks or was installed with incorrect diameter piping. This impedes refrigerant flow and can alter system performance (oil return, pressure drops, etc.).
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: A kink acts like a restriction, causing pressure drop (similar to a partially clogged cap tube) – leading to low suction pressure and reduced capacity. Wrong pipe sizing (too small or too large) can cause improper oil return or reduced efficiency. The compressor may run hotter and capacity may suffer. In severe cases, compressor damage can occur from oil trapping or starving.
common_root_causes: Line set bent too sharply during installation (kinking the copper)
Using existing line set of improper size when replacing unit (e.g., 5/8" instead of 3/4" required suction)
Excessively long line set without proper upsizing or traps, causing oil pooling
Multiple sharp elbows in piping causing equivalent length issues
canonical_symptoms: Lower cooling capacity; possible floodback or starvation depending on scenario
Unusual compressor noise (if oil not returning well or vapor flashing due to restriction)
Service pressures abnormal (e.g., low suction, higher superheat if starved)
If grossly undersized line: compressor overheating, high compression ratio
technician_observation_phrases: visible kink in suction line reducing diameter significantly
line set diameter does not match equipment specifications
oil accumulating in low spots due to improper piping practices
diagnostics.notes: If a kink is accessible, sometimes it can be cut out and the line re-spliced with couplings, or in minor cases carefully expanded back. Wrong line sizing might require line set replacement. Always adhere to manufacturer line length and sizing guidelines, especially for long runs and high lifts (may need oil traps or larger diameter).

diagnostics.description: The aluminum fins on the outdoor condenser coil are flattened or damaged over a large area (e.g., hail damage or pressure washing damage), reducing heat transfer surface area and airflow through the coil.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: Similar to a dirty coil, the condensing becomes less effective. Head pressures rise on hot days, efficiency drops, and capacity can be reduced. Compressor may run hotter and work harder, potentially shortening lifespan or causing high-pressure trips under extreme conditions.
common_root_causes: Hail storm denting the fins across the coil
Improper cleaning technique (using high-pressure water or air against fins)
Vandalism or animal activity (urine from dogs can corrode lower fins, etc.)
Manufacturing defect (rare, usually damage is post-installation)
canonical_symptoms: Unit runs but struggles in heat – high discharge pressure noted
Physically obvious fin damage visible on inspection
Compressor amps higher than normal at a given condition (working harder due to reduced heat rejection)
technician_observation_phrases: condenser fins ~50% bent over in hail impact areas
fins combed out to improve airflow
large side of coil completely flattened
diagnostics.notes: Fin combs can partially restore bent fins if the damage isn’t too severe. In extreme cases, coil replacement might be needed. Hail guards can be installed to protect coils in hail-prone regions, though they must not impede normal airflow.

diagnostics.description: There is no actual equipment fault; the HVAC system is not running because the thermostat (or controller) is turned off or set to a mode where it won't call for heating or cooling. Essentially, user or installer error is at play.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: Obviously, the system remains off (no heating or cooling) despite any expectation of operation. Once the thermostat is turned on or set properly, the system functions normally. This is often discovered after a service call where no defects are found.
common_root_causes: Thermostat left in OFF position (e.g., after season change or by accident)
New thermostat not configured, left in installer setup or in a hold state that effectively turns it off
User unfamiliar with thermostat schedule that might have an off period
canonical_symptoms: HVAC does not run at all – no matter temperature – because thermostat is off
Thermostat display might plainly show 'OFF' mode
Upon switching to cool or heat mode, system immediately engages and works
technician_observation_phrases: thermostat was in off position upon arrival
no call for heat/cool due to thermostat being off
diagnostics.notes: This is the simplest 'diagnosis' – no repair needed, just user education. It's surprisingly common, especially when transitioning seasons or after power outages (some thermostats default to off). We mark it as no-fault user error.

diagnostics.specific_diagnostic_name: System performing normally under extreme conditions
diagnostics.description: The system is functioning as designed, but due to extremely high or low outdoor temperatures (or other boundary conditions), it cannot maintain indoor comfort perfectly. In other words, there's no equipment fault – conditions are just beyond its capabilities or design assumptions.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: Indoor temperatures might rise above the thermostat setting in a severe heat wave, or drop below setting in a cold snap, even though the HVAC is running constantly. Humidity might climb if AC can’t cycle enough, etc. Once weather moderates, the system keeps up fine. Essentially, it's a capacity limitation, not a failure.
common_root_causes: Outdoor conditions exceed the equipment design parameters (e.g., heat pump at -10°F providing limited heat, or AC in 100°F+ struggling)
Home gained unusual heat load (e.g., party with many people, or open windows) not normally accounted for
User expects unrealistic performance (e.g., trying to cool house to 65°F when it's 105°F outside)
canonical_symptoms: System runs non-stop but indoor temp creeps beyond setpoint during peak hours
No error codes or obvious mechanical issues, just not meeting comfort on worst days
Building gradually loses ground overnight in extreme cold despite system operating
technician_observation_phrases: system pressures and amps normal for high load, just load exceeds capacity
informed homeowner that 75°F inside at 100°F ambient is actually expected performance
diagnostics.notes: This outcome often results in advice: e.g., add supplemental cooling/heating or improve insulation for extremes, but technically the HVAC is OK. Clarifying expectations and perhaps upsizing during replacement might be discussion points. Documentation of design conditions versus actual weather can support that system is normal.
